IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAB 2430 S1381-1177(12)00069-0 10.1016/j.molcatb.2012.03.010 Fig. 1 Process scheme of the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation broth without prior purification. Fig. 2 Chemical catalyst screening for the biphasic esterification of succinic with different alcohols: conversion of succinic acid from the aqueous phase after 24h. Reaction conditions: 80°C, 0.8M succinic acid in distilled water at pH 2.1, 10mol % DBSA or 0.5g heterogeneous catalysts, 5ml aqueous phase, 5ml alcohol. Catalysts tested: DBSA , Nafion NR-50 , PS-sulf. ac. , Amberlyst 131 and Nafion SAC . Fig. 3 Enzyme screening for the biphasic esterification of succinic acid at different temperatures: conversion of succinic acid from the aqueous phase after 24h. Reaction conditions: 0.15M succinic acid in phosphate buffer (43mM) at pH 4, 40mg or 40μg, 5ml aqueous phase, 5ml 1-octanol. Temperature: 30°C , 50°C and 70°C (N.D.=not determined). Fig. 4 Impact of the pH on the esterification of succinic acid with 1-octanol in biphasic system with DBSA (a), Nafion NR-50 (b) and Novozym 435 (c): conversion of succinic acid from the aqueous phase after 4h , 6h , 8h and 24h . Reaction conditions: 0.8M for (a) and (b) or 0.15M succinic acid in phosphate buffer (43mM) at different pH, 131mg DBSA(a), 0.5g Nafion NR-50 (b) or 40mg Novozym 435 (c), 80°C (a and b) or 50°C (c), 5ml aqueous phase, 5ml 1-octanol. Fig. 5 Arrhenius’ plot for esterification of succinic acid with 1-octanol in biphasic system with DBSA (●), Nafion NR-50 (■) and Novozym 435 (▽): natural logarithm of the initial rate constant of succinic acid consumption vs. 1/T. Reaction conditions: 0.8M (for DBSA and Nafion NR-50) or 0.15M (for Novozym 435) succinic acid in phosphate buffer (43mM) at pH 2 for DBSA and Nafion NR-50 or pH 4 for Novozym 435, 131mg DBSA, 0.5g Nafion NR-50 or 40mg Novozym 435, 5ml aqueous phase, 5ml 1-octanol. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Process integration of fermentation and catalysis for succinate ester production. ► Screening of chemical and biological catalysts for the esterification. ► The reaction conditions were optimized for the best three catalysts. ► Succinic acid was directly esterified in the fermentation broth (X max =93%). ► Succinate esters from the broth were recovered with a purity of 83%. Different chemical and biological catalysts were screened for the biphasic esterification of aqueous solutions of succinic acid with 1-octanol. Among them, DBSA, Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 were found to be the most attractive catalysts. The pH, the temperature and the catalyst concentration had high impacts on the reaction rates. The optimization of the reaction conditions with a single-variable approach for the chemical catalysts and a Response Surface Methodology for the enzyme allowed an increase of the rates by a factor 1.5 for DBSA, 2.3 for Nafion NR-50 and 1.3 for Novozym 435. Real fermentation broths produced from recombinant Escherichia coli could be successfully esterified with conversions up to 93% for DBSA and 70% for Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 as catalysts. Finally, DBSA was selected as the cheapest and most active option. Besides, the esters were isolated with a purity of 83% from fermentation broth solutions. DBSA also catalyzed the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation broth with many alcohols creating a broad spectrum of interesting esters. The esters might then be used as end-product, hydrolyzed back to pure succinic acid or hydrogenated. Keywords Biphasic esterification Succinic acid DBSA Nafion NR-50 Novozym 435 Reactive extraction 1 Introduction Succinic acid is a C4 chemical often reported as promising bio-feedstock chemical for biorefineries [1,2]. This dicarboxylic acid is an intermediate of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle that could replace maleic anhydride produced from oil as C4 building block chemical. It can be used for the production of a wide range of derivatives, especially its reduced products [3]. In this study, the production of its esters will be examined in more detail, as they have a broad range of applications in the chemical [4–6], the pharmaceutical [7–9], the food [10] and the cosmetic industries [11]. As for the synthesis of succinic acid itself, its biotechnological production of the succinic acid has been widely investigated in the last decade. Mostly natural succinate producing microorganisms (e.g. Actinobacillus succinogenes and Mannheimia succiniproducens) and engineered Escherichia coli, Corynebacterium glutamicum and Saccharomyces cerevisiae have been successfully studied to this aim, with final concentrations up to 110g/l [12–14]. One of the bottlenecks of this process is, however, the expensive purification of succinic acid [13,15,16]. As succinic acid is an intermediate, it would be profitable to perform the esterification directly in the fermentation broth so that the expensive purification of succinic acid would not be necessary (see Fig. 1 ). The formed esters would have different physico-chemical properties that would ease their purification. However, it is challenging to perform a dehydrative reaction, such as an esterification, in water. Furthermore, the side products or the medium components of the fermentation could deactivate or inhibit the catalysts. For the esterification of carboxylic acids, two types of catalysts can be used: chemical catalysts (mainly Brønsted or Lewis acids) or enzymes (lipases or esterases). For succinic acid, several chemical catalysts have been reported for the esterification in pure organic solvents or pure alcohols: montmorillonite clay catalysts [10,17,18] and Amberlyst 15 resin [19]. Regarding the alternatives for aqueous solutions of succinic acid, only short chain alcohols have been tested in mono- or biphasic systems. Starbon®, a starch-derived mesoporous material has been tested successfully for the esterification of short chain alcohols such as ethanol or methanol [20–22]. Amberlyst XN-1010 and Nafion® NR-50 have also been used for the esterification with ethanol using pervaporation [23]. Finally, Bauduin et al. [24] tested two alternatives for the aqueous esterification of succinic acid with 1-butanol: homogeneous catalysts, such as p-TsOH, methanesulfonic acid, 4-(dimethylamino)-pyridin or tertiary amines, and heterogeneous catalysts, such as Amberlyst 15, Amberlyst 19 or DPT-1. Regarding the enzymes, the esterification of succinic acid with ethanol in organic solvents (tetradecan, octan, diphyl KT) has been tested with different lipases, such as Novozym® 435 – the lipase B from Candida antarctica immobilized on acrylic resin [25]. The same enzyme has been successfully used for the esterification of succinic acid with oleyl alcohol in hexane [26]. No enzymatic esterification of aqueous solutions of succinic acid has been reported to date to the best of our knowledge. As few alternatives have been suggested for the esterification of succinic acid in aqueous media, this study will focus on the esterification of aqueous solutions of this compound in biphasic systems. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (DBSA) (Fluka), Nafion® NR-50 (Aldrich), Polystyren sulfonic acid (PS-sulf.ac.) (Rapp Polymere), Amberlyst 131 (Sigma) and Nafion® SAC (Aldrich), lipase from Burkholderia cepacia (BCL), immobilized lipase B from Candida antarctica (Novozym® 435) (Sigma) (Aldrich), lipase from Candida rugosa (CRL) (Sigma), lipase from Thermomyces lanuginosus (TLL) (Sigma), lipoprotein lipase from Chromobacterium viscosum (CVLPL) (Fluka), lipoprotein lipase from Pseudomonas sp. (PSLPL) (Fluka) and Amano lipase from Pseudomonas fluorescens (PFL), succinic acid (Merk), and other chemicals were purchased from various suppliers. 2.2 Esterification on the 10-ml scale The esterification of succinic acid with chemical catalysts was realized in a Carousel 12 Reaction Station from Radleys (Essex, UK) equipped with a stirring hot plate RTC basic from KIKA Labortechnik, IKA (Staufen, Germany) and a temperature controller EKT Hei-Con from Heidolph (Schwabach, Germany). The stirring was achieved magnetically with cross-shaped stirrers. The esterification with enzymes was realized with a prototype of 8 parallel, magnetically inductive driven stirred-tank bioreactors on a 10-ml scale, provided by 2mag AG, (Munich, Germany) [27]. The solutions were agitated with so-called S-stirrers designed for the homogenisation of particle suspensions at high solid content [28]. The catalyst and 5ml of the aqueous phase containing 0.8M or 0.15M succinic acid in distilled water or in the fermentation broth were added into the reaction vessels and sealed with the cap. The tubes were heated at the reaction temperature under reflux. In order to start the reaction, 5ml of 1-octanol (or another alcohol) were added. Samples were taken every hour until 8h as well as after 24h. The aqueous phase was analyzed by HPLC in order to determine the remaining succinic acid concentration. 2.3 Esterification on the 200-ml scale The esterification with dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (DBSA) was realized at a 200-ml scale in a round bottom flask placed in an oil bath, the temperature of which was controlled with a temperature controller EKT Hei-Con from Heidolph (Schwabach, Germany). The solution was magnetically agitated at 800rpm. 100ml of the aqueous phase (either pure solution of succinic acid or fermentation broth) were placed in the flask with 2.62g DBSA and heated at 90°C under reflux. When the temperature of 90°C was reached, 100ml of 1-octanol was added. The emulsion was let stirred for 8h. The reaction mixture was cooled down and the phases were then separated by centrifugation for the pure solution of succinic acid or by simple settling for the broth. The aqueous phase was analyzed by HPLC in order to determine the conversion of succinic acid. The organic phase was further treated to separate the esters. 2.4 Purification of the esters The organic phase of the 200-ml esterification with DBSA was placed in a rotary evaporator Laborotha 4003 from Heidolph (Schwabach, Germany) at 130°C and 5mbar for 5h in order to evaporate the 1-octanol contained in the organic phase and to recover the esters. The latter were analyzed by 1H NMR to verify their nature. The esters were then filtered on silica gel using dichloromethane as solvent. The dichloromethane was finally evaporated in a rotary evaporator and the esters were analyzed again by 1H NMR. 2.5 Analytics The succinic acid content of the aqueous phase was analyzed by HPLC (Agilent 1100 Series, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) on an Aminex HPX-87H column (Bio-rad Laboratories, Inc., Hercules, CA, USA) maintained at 55°C. Succinic acid was detected by a RI detector (1200 Serie G1362A, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) (retention time: 10.0min) and an UV detector (S 3300, Knauer, Berlin, Germany) (retention time: 9.8min). The eluent phase was an aqueous solution of 5mM sulfuric acid at 0.7ml/min. 2.6 Calculations of the initial consumption rate constant For the calculation of the initial consumption rate constant (or “rate constant”), the disappearance of the aqueous succinic acid [SA] aq was first fitted by an exponential decay given by Eq. (1) using the program SigmaPlot® (Systat Softwater Inc., Chicago, IL). (1) S A a q = m + a ⋅ e − b ⋅ t The initial consumption rate constant (or simply “rate constant”) k tot,0 was then calculated from Eq. (2). (2) k t o t , 0 = 1 S A t o t , 0 d S A a q d t t = 0 = − a ⋅ b S A t o t , 0 with k tot,0 (initial consumption) rate constant (h−1); [SA] tot,0 initial total concentration of succinic acid in the aqueous phase before contact of the two phases (moll−1). 2.7 Optimization The optimization of the reaction conditions for the esterification of succinic acid with both enzymes and chemical catalysts was first realized with a single-variable strategy, varying the variables one at the time while keeping the others constant. The optimal conditions were then chosen as the set of the optimal variables derived separately. For the enzymatic esterification, a second optimization was realized using a Response Surface Methodology (RSM). The RSM technique consists in optimally planning and performing a series of experiments by varying the input variables and fitting the responses with second order polynomial functions with interaction terms. This methodology was used for optimizing the initial rate constant of succinic acid with the temperature (30–70°C), the pH (2–4) and the succinic acid initial concentration (0.15–0.8M) as input variables. The reactions were performed in triplicate. For the 3-variable RSM optimization, the experiments were planned following the faced Central Composite Design (CCD). The computational calculations were realized with Matlab (Mathworks 2010a) with the least square method. The optimal conditions were derived from the fitted polynomial function. 3 Results and discussion In the first part of this study, pure aqueous solutions of succinic acid were tested on a 10-ml scale for a first characterisation and optimization of the reaction conditions. In the second part, real fermentation broths from a recombinant E. coli succinic acid producer were used instead, to characterize the best catalyst and develop the purification steps of the esters. 3.1 Catalyst screening: chemical and enzymatic esterification For the chemical catalysts, a preparatory experiment (data not shown) established that the one-phase esterification with ethanol led to low yields of diethyl esters (below 50%) if water was introduced in the ethanol phase for the 15 catalysts screened. That is why a biphasic strategy was selected for further process development. This type of reaction has the advantages of combining both the esterification of succinic acid and the extraction of the esters in the organic phase limiting their potential hydrolysis and facilitating their purification. Furthermore water-immiscible alcohols can be used as second phase to limit the use of organic solvents. The best five catalysts selected from the preparatory experiment were tested with different alcohols for the esterification of succinic acid in biphasic system as shown in Fig. 2 . The chemical catalysts tested were: dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (DBSA), Nafion NR-50, Polystyrene sulfonic acid (PS-sulf.ac.), Amberlyst 131 and Nafion SAC-13. The alcohol had a high impact on the conversion of succinic acid. For the shortest chain alcohol (1-butanol), high conversions from 69 to 93% could be reached after 24h. However, as the chain length of the alcohol increased, the conversions strongly dropped for the heterogeneous catalysts whereas the only homogeneous catalyst – the surfactant DBSA – kept good conversions with all the alcohols tested (≥87%). This could be due to the increasing hydrophobicity of the organic phase with the alcohol chain length, so that water might be preferentially absorbed in the pores of the heterogeneous catalysts. The high concentration of water in the pores probably increases the hydrolysis of the esters [29] and reduces the contact between the two phases. The only heterogeneous catalyst that could maintain satisfactory conversion (75%) with 1-octanol was Nafion NR-50. Unfortunately, short chain alcohols such as 1-butanol and 1-hexanol are unsuitable for biphasic applications because they have high water solubilities: 80g 1-butanol/L (20°C) and 6g 1-hexanol/L (25°C). High quantities of alcohol would hence be lost in the aqueous phase, preventing the complete recycling of the alcohol excess. On the contrary, 1-octanol (water solubility: 0.30mg/l at 20°C) can be used as second phase for the esterification of succinic acid with both DBSA and Nafion NR-50 (initial rate constants of succinic acid consumption: 0.329±0.009 and 0.036±0.020h−1 resp.). The biphasic strategy with these two catalysts was hence further investigated. In addition, seven lipases were tested for the biphasic esterification of succinic acid with 1-octanol at 30°C, 50°C and 70°C, as presented in Fig. 3 . The enzymes tested were: the lipase from Burkholderia cepacia (BCL), the immobilized lipase B from Candida antarctica (Novozym 435), the lipase from Candida rugosa (CRL), the lipase from Thermomyces lanuginosus (TLL), the lipoprotein lipase from Chromobacterium viscosum (CVLPL), the lipoprotein lipase from Pseudomonas sp. (PSLPL) and the Amano lipase from Pseudomonas fluorescens (PFL). The two lipoprotein lipases were the enzymes with which the highest conversions (i.e. 60% with the CVLPL and 58% with the PSLPL) could be achieved after 24h. For the CVLPL, the final conversions were even reached after 4h at 30°C and 3h at 50°C. An increase of the temperature from 30°C to 50°C was favourable for the CVLPL, whereas it deactivated the PSLPL. However, a further increase of the temperature up to 70°C reduced dramatically the final conversion (22%) of the CVLPL. Finally, the highest initial succinic acid consumption rate constants were achieved with CVLPL at 50°C (0.843±0.036h−1) and with PSLPL at 30°C (0.340±0.069h−1). The third best enzyme was the Novozym 435 with conversions of 34%, 41% and 47% at 30°C, 50°C and 70°C. As reported in the literature [30], this enzyme is thermostable and enabled higher activities with increasing temperatures (up to 0.036±0.002h−1 at 70°C). Unfortunately, lipoprotein lipases are extremely expensive (2010€/g for CVLPL and 688€/g for PSLPL), whereas Novozym 435 has a relatively low price (20€/g) (source: Sigma–Aldrich, 2010). That is why the enhancement in activity does not compensate the higher cost due to the use of the lipoprotein lipases. Therefore, Novozym 435 is a less expensive alternative with relatively good activity. Furthermore, it has the advantage of being already immobilized, simplifying purification steps. Finally, DBSA (a homogeneous surfactant), Nafion NR-50 (a heterogeneous fluorinated polymer) and Novozym 435 (an immobilized lipase on acrylic resin) were chosen as promising catalysts for the esterification of succinic acid with 1-octanol in a biphasic process. The reaction conditions for the catalysis using these three catalysts were then optimized. 3.2 Impact of reaction conditions The impact of different reaction conditions (pH, temperature and catalyst concentrations) were separately tested on the esterification of succinic acid with 1-octanol with the three best catalysts selected previously, using a single-variable strategy (see Subchapter 2.7). Besides, the agitation rate and the initial succinic acid concentrations (0.05–0.8M) did not show any effect on the yields achieved with the three catalysts (data not shown). 3.2.1 Impact of the pH The pH could be an important factor for the development of the esterification of succinic acid since the substrate of the reaction is a dicarboxylic acid. Furthermore, the chemical catalysts are Brønsted acids and enzymes are often only active within a particular pH range. As shown in Fig. 4 , the pH had a significant impact on the conversions of succinic acid from the aqueous phase both with chemical (DBSA (a) and Nafion (b)) and enzymatic catalysts (c). For the two chemical catalysts, the final conversions after 24h were relatively limited (≤23%) for pH≥4, whereas good conversions after 24h could be achieved in buffers at pH 2 and pH 3 (for DBSA, 91% and 89%, and for Nafion NR-50, 71% and 55% resp.). However, a decrease of the initial succinic acid consumption rate constant could be observed from pH 2 to 3 for both DBSA and Nafion NR-50: the initial rate constant decreased from 0.326±0.013h−1 to 0.171±0.005h−1 for DBSA and from 0.036±0.010h−1 to 0.024±0.008h−1 for Nafion NR-50. This loss in activity of 48% (DBSA) and 33% (Nafion NR-50) might be correlated to the pK a of the catalyst (e.g. pK a,DBSA =2.55 [31]). Since the catalyst acts as a proton donor to the carbonyl function, only the protonated form of the catalyst might catalyze the esterification. This could be confirmed by calculating the rate constants per mmol protonated DBSA and finding similar values at pH 2 and 3 (0.93±0.4 and 0.82±0.02h−1 mmol protonated DBSA−1 resp.). The loss in activity is, therefore, most probably due to the decrease of the amount of the protonated active form of the catalyst at initial pH≥3. In conclusion, optimal activities and conversions for the two chemical catalysts could be reached at pH 2. As for the enzyme, the impact of the pH was more complex (see Fig. 4c). On the one hand, pHs above 5 dramatically diminished the final conversions (≤9%). On the other hand, lower pHs (pH<2) had a negative impact on the final conversions (conversion of only 22% at pH 1.5). These two effects resulted on a maximum of the conversion after 24h at pH 3 (i.e. 68%). The moderate conversions at lower pH can be explained by a partial deactivation of the enzyme. Buthe et al. [32] and Domínguez de María et al. [33] explained the loss in activity at higher pH by the protonated form of the carboxylic acid being the only possible substrate of the lipase. In this study, a similar decrease of the activity above the first pK a of succinic acid (pK a1 =4.21) could be observed. For initial concentrations of succinic acid of 0.15M and at initial pHs≥4, the initial concentrations of the diprotonated succinic acid are indeed lower than 0.09M, limiting hence the final conversions. Finally at pH≥6, almost no diprotonated substrate (≤0.002M) is available for the enzymes. Buthe et al. [32] suggested that electrostatic repulsions could repel the substrate out of the active site. That could explain why the negatively charged monoprotonated succinic acid cannot be used as substrate even if it bears a protonated carboxylic acid on one side. In conclusion, optimal pH for the enzymatic esterification of succinic acid with 1-octanol in biphasic system using Novozym 435 as catalyst lies around pH 3. 3.2.2 Impact of the temperature The temperature has also a large impact on catalytic reactions and especially on enzyme catalysts that do not always show high thermal stability. For the chemical catalysts, temperature can also cause catalyst denaturing. Furthermore, as the rate of the reaction increases with the temperature, mass transfer can become limiting. For the chemical catalysts, the impact of the temperature was tested from 50°C to 90°C and for the enzymatic catalysis, milder temperatures were screened (30–70°C) as enzymes are often less thermostable. The results are presented in the form of Arrhenius plots in Fig. 5 . For the three catalysts, an increase of the temperature led to an enhancement of the activity. However, for DBSA and especially for Novozym 435, the activity seemed to increase slower at high temperatures. For Novozym 435, this could be due to a partial deactivation of the enzyme (e.g. due to changes in the 3D-structure). In the case of DBSA, high rate constants were indeed reported at 90°C (0.361±0.002h−1) so that the mass transfer between the two phases might become limiting. As for Nafion NR-50, the Arrhenius’ law seemed to be valid for the whole range of temperatures tested. The activation energies calculated from the Arrhenius’ law were of 68±7kJmol−1, 37±2kJmol−1 and 43±3kJmol−1 for DBSA, Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435. The reaction mechanism should be similar for DBSA and Nafion NR-50 since both catalysts bear sulfonic groups. That is why similar activation energies would have been expected. However, the reaction in the heterogeneous catalyst could be limited by pore diffusion, leading to an apparent activation energy about half of the real one. That indeed comes close to the estimated value. Similar activation energies (61kJmol−1) have been reported for the esterification of acetic acid with methanol using sulfuric acid when water was introduced in the system [34]. For Novozym 435, the activation energy is intermediate. However, the reaction mechanism is different [35], so that the estimated values cannot be compared. In conclusions, higher temperatures were found optimal for all three catalysts and no complete deactivation could be observed. 3.2.3 Impact of the catalyst concentration The impact of the catalyst concentration can give information on potential mass transfer limitations. The experimental results are presented in Fig. 6 . For the three catalysts, the rate constant at low catalyst concentrations was proportional to the mass of the catalyst. However as the mass increased, a levelling off of the activity occurred, especially for DBSA. This can be due to mass transfer limitation in the pores in the case of the two heterogeneous catalysts or in the case of the three catalysts to external mass transfer. The hypothesis of internal mass transfer limitations might be tested using heterogeneous catalysts with different pore or bead sizes. However, those were not available. As for DBSA, the levelling off of the rate constant can be explained by external mass transfer limitation. Furthermore, DBSA being a surfactant, the increase of the catalyst concentration should also increase the interfacial area, but above 131mg of catalyst, the bubbles of the emulsions might keep a constant diameter, the additional DBSA staying in the bulk of the organic phase, where mass transfer could be limiting. In industry, the optimal catalyst concentration is often taken slightly above the linear range, in order to have high activities but not to add a high quantity of catalyst that would not be used at its full capacity. Following this rule, the optimal concentrations were selected as 131mg for DBSA, 750mg for Nafion NR-50 and 60mg for Novozym 435. 3.3 Optimized conditions and three-variable optimization for the enzymatic catalysis Optimal conditions were derived from the previously presented single-variable experiments. Taking the optimal set of conditions as the best conditions found by separate screening is, however, based on the assumption that the reaction variables are independent. These optimal sets of reaction conditions were tested for the esterification of succcinic acid with 1-octanol in biphasic systems using DBSA, Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435. The comparison of the standard conditions and the optimized conditions is reported in Table 1 (entries 1–3). For DBSA and Nafion NR-50, the optimal conditions derived from the study of the variables separately allowed the increase of the initial consumption rate constant by a factor 1.5 for DBSA and 2.3 for Nafion NR-50. Hence, DBSA allowed the reaction to reach the equilibrium at 91% conversion after only 8h. The optimization for Nafion NR-50 allowed an increase of the conversion after 24h from 66% to 84%. As for Novozym 435, the set of optimized variables gave surprisingly a complete deactivation of the enzyme with only 22% conversion, mostly corresponding to the pure extraction of succinic acid into the 1-octanol phase at pH 3. Enzyme stability has been reported to be sensitive to both temperature and pH. At high temperature, the hydrogen bonds are indeed weakened. Besides, lower pHs can cause changes in the electrostatic interactions between the charged amino acids. Finally low pH and high temperature can cause deamination through peptide bond hydrolysis. As both the pH (from pH 4 to pH 3) and the temperature (from 50°C to 70°C) were simultaneously changed from the standard conditions to the optimal set of variables, a loss of the 3D-structure of the enzyme might have happened. These two variables cannot be supposed to be independent as they both have impacts on the 3D-structure of the enzyme. A multi-variable Response Surface Methodology (RSM) optimization was hence specially realized for the enzymatic esterification, with the temperature, the pH and the succinic acid concentration as 3 input-variables and the initial consumption rate constant as output-variable to be maximised. A simple second order polynomial function with interaction terms could fit well the experimental data (R 2 =0.9558, Adj. R =0.9227 and P value=5.31×10−5) (see subchapter 2.7). The set of new optimized conditions that was derived from the empirical RSM optimization was tested for the esterification. The outcome is presented in Table 1 (entry 4). This new optimized set of reaction conditions gave an increase of the initial rate constant by a factor 1.3 and allowed the enhancement of the conversions after 24h from 47% to 72%. The rate constant predicted by the polynomial function (0.045h−1) was close to the one measured experimentally (0.042±0.001h−1). 3.4 Esterification of fermentation broth To test the influence of the fermentation broth on the esterification, the impact of different medium components and side products was first assessed separately. To do so, several solutions of pure succinic acid were prepared in distilled water with one additional compound such as a medium component or a side product often found in E. coli fermentation broths for the production of succinic acid [36]. These solutions were tested in the optimal conditions derived previously for the three catalysts and compared with a pure solution of succinic acid and a real fermentation broth from E. coli containing 0.257M of succinic acid. The pH of the fermentation broth was set to pH 2 for the chemical catalysts and to pH 3.33 for the enzyme by addition of HCl. The results are summarized in Table 2 . For the chemical catalysts, only high concentrations of phosphate salts (entry 5) seemed to have a negative impact on the final conversions. Conversions of only 83% and 67% with DBSA and Nafion NR-50 could indeed be achieved in solutions containing high concentrations of phosphate (entry 5) whereas 91% and 84% were obtained in pure solutions of succinic acid (entry 15). The other medium components and side products did not change the final conversions much (89–91% for DBSA and 80–84% for Nafion NR-50). In the real fermentation broth, the conversions were of 78% using DBSA and of 70% using Nafion NR-50. For the latter catalyst, the high concentration of salts in the phosphate solution (entry 5) and in the fermentation broth (entry 16) might be responsible for the exchange of small cations (K+ and Na+) with the H+ of the resins partially deactivating the catalyst. As for DBSA, the lower conversions obtained in the case of high phosphate concentration and in the fermentation broth could be explained by the fact that high concentrations of salts (≥10g/l) might reduce the interfacial tension and destabilized the emulsion [37]. If the emulsion is not formed, the surface area where the surfactant catalyst is in contact with the two phases is strongly reduced and so are therefore the activity and the final conversions. Finally, higher concentrations of DBSA were tested to see if the emulsion could be restored (data not shown). In fermentation broth, similar conversions after 8h (93%) as the one achieved in distilled water could ultimately be achieved by doubling the quantity of DBSA (262mg). As for the enzyme, the conversions are varying less (from 66% to 75%) even with high phosphate concentrations. No real tendency could be derived from the data. Finally, the conversions obtained with the fermentation broth and the pure solution of succinic acid were very similar (70% and 68%). The enzyme is, therefore, not inhibited by any component or side product from the fermentation broth. In conclusion, the three catalysts could be used for the esterification of succinic acid in fermentation broth without high loss in activity in comparison with pure solutions of succinic acid. 3.5 Comparison of the catalysts, cost and reuse After testing the impact of the medium components and side products, the evolution of the conversion of succinic acid in the fermentation broth with the three catalysts was compared and the comparison is presented in Fig. 7 (the higher concentration of DBSA (262mg) mentioned earlier was used). Conversions of 94% after 8h for DBSA, 70% after 24h for Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 were determined. The initial rate constants of succinic acid consumption were of 0.295±0.008h−1 for DBSA, 0.036±0.002h−1 for Nafion NR-50 and 0.050±0.001h−1 for Novozym 435. Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 are two immobilized catalysts that can be easily removed from the reaction solution, but their activity is at least 6 times lower than the activity of DBSA. The latter cannot easily be recycled, but it presented high activity that allowed the reaction to be completed in 8h. Nafion NR-50 or Novozym 435 reached similar conversions (90 and 76%) only after 72h. DBSA seems, therefore, to be the most active catalyst among the three tested. However, in order to select the best option for the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation in two-phase system with 1-octanol, the costs must still be taken into account. Catalyst costs per gram of diester produced in 8h (DBSA) or 24h (Nafion NR-50 or Novozym 435) are presented in Fig. 8 . DBSA is about 800 times less expensive than Novozym 435 and 300 times than Nafion NR-50. The use of the two latter catalysts is, therefore, only possible if they could be recycled at least a few hundred times. In conclusion, DBSA seems to be the most promising alternative for the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation broth in biphasic system. However the use of a homogeneous catalyst could contaminate the product. That is why the purification of the ester must still be examined. 3.6 Larger scale esterification and purification In order to analyze the feasibility of the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation broth with DBSA, the reaction was realized at a 200-ml scale using fermentation broth and pure solution of succinic acid as a comparison (both with 2.52g DBSA for 100ml of aqueous solution). The reactions were stopped after 8h and the conversions were determined. The phases were then separated by centrifugation for the pure solution of succinic acid or by simple settling for the broth. 1-Octanol was then evaporated out of the organic phase. The recovered esters were then analyzed by 1H NMR. It could be confirmed that the diester and not the monoester was obtained as product. The esters were then filtered on silica gel with dichloromethane and analyzed again by 1H NMR. The results of the conversions and purities are summarized in Table 3 . The conversions (91% for the pure solution and 85% for the broth) were similar to those obtained at the 10-ml scale (91% and 78%, respectively, see Table 2, entries 15 and 16). The purity of the esters produced from the pure solution of succinic acid was high (90%) whereas it remained limited for the esters from the fermentation broth (63%). Besides, it should be noted that the purities determined by 1H NMR were extremely similar to the ones calculated from the mass of esters obtained and the conversions. Moreover, the extracted succinic acid into the 1-octanol phase should not contaminate much the esters (∼1%, based on calculations), while DBSA was found in limited amount in the esters (up to 6%). In order to reduce the DBSA and the side products contamination, the esters were filtered on silica gel. After filtration, the purity was considerably improved for the fermentation broth (83%) as well as for the pure solution of succinic acid (95%). The lower purity of the esters from the fermentation broth before filtration is probably due to the extraction of different less polar side products or medium components from the fermentation broth into the 1-octanol phase. Furthermore, other carboxylic acids from the fermentation broth might also have been esterified by DBSA and extracted in the 1-octanol phase. Finally, 1-octanol can be recovered with a purity of ∼98% (determination by 1H NMR) after the purification of the ester. It can hence be reused for further esterifications of succinic acid as it is introduced in excess. In conclusion, DBSA allowed the esterification of succinic acid in two-phase systems with conversions up to 93%. For the reaction with fermentation broth, the esters could be recovered with a purity of 83%. 3.7 Application of the process As shown previously, DBSA can efficiently esterify succinic acid present in a fermentation broth into its dioctyl esters that can be used as solvent, intermediate for organic synthesis and antifreezing agent [38]. The process was developed with 1-octanol, but DBSA can also esterify succinic acid with 1-butanol, 1-hexanol, 1-nonanol, 1-decanol and 1-undecanol at high conversions (≥87%) (shown in Fig. 2). Other interesting alcohols were also tested for the esterification in the fermentation broth using DBSA with conversions after 24h of 94, 95, 85, 92 and 90% for isobutylalcohol, isoamylalcohol, benzyl alcohol, 1-decanol and 1-dodecanol respectively. In conclusion, DBSA can be used to synthesize a broad range of esters with market potential. Besides, the esterification of succinic acid in a biphasic system can be used as reactive extraction of the carboxylic acid from the broth. The hydrophobic esters are indeed much more easily extracted in the organic phase than succinic acid. The formed esters can then be hydrolyzed back in succinic acid. This possibility was tested in biphasic systems of water and dioctyl esters. Novozym® 435 and DBSA gave successful hydrolyses with conversions up to 81 and 76% with relatively small esters:water volumetric ratios (1:10 (v/v)) achieving succinic acid concentrations of 0.25M and 0.24M. 4 Conclusions Whereas lipoprotein lipases were highly active but too expensive, DBSA, Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 were found to be the most attractive catalysts for the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation broth with 1-octanol in two-phase systems. DBSA remained the cheapest and most active option with conversions of 78–93% after only 8h of reaction in the broth. The esters could be isolated with a purity of 83% from fermentation broth solutions. Furthermore, DBSA can catalyze the esterification of succinic acid with many alcohols at conversions ≥87%, creating a broad spectrum of interesting esters. The esters could then be used as final product, hydrolyzed back to pure succinic acid or hydrogenated to succinic acid reduced products (e.g. gamma-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol and tetrahydrofuran). coredata.dc:description: Different chemical and biological catalysts were screened for the biphasic esterification of aqueous solutions of succinic acid with 1-octanol. Among them, DBSA, Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 were found to be the most attractive catalysts. The pH, the temperature and the catalyst concentration had high impacts on the reaction rates. The optimization of the reaction conditions with a single-variable approach for the chemical catalysts and a Response Surface Methodology for the enzyme allowed an increase of the rates by a factor 1.5 for DBSA, 2.3 for Nafion NR-50 and 1.3 for Novozym 435. Real fermentation broths produced from recombinant Escherichia coli could be successfully esterified with conversions up to 93% for DBSA and 70% for Nafion NR-50 and Novozym 435 as catalysts. Finally, DBSA was selected as the cheapest and most active option. Besides, the esters were isolated with a purity of 83% from fermentation broth solutions. DBSA also catalyzed the esterification of succinic acid from fermentation broth with many alcohols creating a broad spectrum of interesting esters. The esters might then be used as end-product, hydrolyzed back to pure succinic acid or hydrogenated.
coredata.dc:title: Esterification of bio-based succinic acid in biphasic systems: Comparison of chemical and biological catalysts
